Edge atomic Fe sites decorated porous graphitic carbon as an efficient bifunctional oxygen catalyst for Zinc-air batteries Ruihui Gan a Yali Wang a Xiangwu Zhang b Yan Song c Jingli Shi a Chang Ma a ⁎ a Tianjin Municipal Key Lab of Advanced Fiber and Energy Storage Technology, Tiangong University, Tianjin 300387, China Tianjin Municipal Key Lab of Advanced Fiber and Energy Storage Technology Tiangong University Tianjin 300387 China Tianjin Municipal Key Lab of Advanced Fiber and Energy Storage Technology, Tiangong University, Tianjin 300387, China b Fiber and Polymer Science Program, Department of Textile Engineering, Chemistry and Science, Wilson College of Textiles, North Carolina State University, Raleigh, NC 27695-8301, United States Fiber and Polymer Science Program Department of Textile Engineering, Chemistry and Science Wilson College of Textiles North Carolina State University Raleigh NC 27695-8301 United States Fiber and Polymer Science Program, Department of Textile Engineering, Chemistry and Science, Wilson College of Textiles, North Carolina State University, Raleigh, NC 27695-8301, United States c CAS Key Laboratory of Carbon Materials, Institute of Coal Chemistry, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Taiyuan 030001, Shanxi, China CAS Key Laboratory of Carbon Materials Institute of Coal Chemistry Chinese Academy of Sciences Taiyuan 030001 Shanxi China CAS Key Laboratory of Carbon Materials, Institute of Coal Chemistry, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Taiyuan 030001, Shanxi, China ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract The edge Fe sites located in the graphitic layer achieved efficient and robust ORR performance, and they were converted to FeOOH species in OER and synergized with the graphitic layer. The development of advanced bifunctional oxygen electrocatalysts for oxygen reduction and evolution reactions (ORR and OER) is critical to the practical application of zinc-air batteries (ZABs). Herein, a silica-assisted method is reported to integrate numerous accessible edge Fe-Nx sites into porous graphitic carbon (named Fe-N-G) for achieving highly active and robust oxygen electrocatalysis. Silica facilitates the formation of edge Fe-Nx sites and dense graphitic domains in carbon by inhibiting iron aggregation. The purification process creates a well-developed mass transfer channel for Fe-N-G. Consequently, Fe-N-G delivers a half-wave potential of 0.859 V in ORR and an overpotential of 344 mV at 10 mA cm−2 in OER. During long-term operation, the graphitic layers protect edge Fe-Nx sites from demetallation in ORR and synergize with FeOOH species endowing Fe-N-G with enhanced OER activity. Density functional theory calculations reveal that the edge Fe-Nx site is superior to the in-plane Fe-Nx site in terms of OH* dissociation in ORR and OOH* formation in OER. The constructed ZAB based on Fe-N-G cathode shows a higher peak power density of 133 mW cm−2 and more stable cycling performance than Pt/C + RuO2 counterparts. This work provides a novel strategy to obtain high-efficiency bifunctional oxygen electrocatalysts through space mediation. Keywords Bifunctionality Edge Fe-Nx sites Oxygen catalysis Graphitic domains Zinc-air batteries 1 Introduction Zinc-air batteries (ZABs) have attracted widespread attention as a next-generation energy storage system to cope with the energy crisis, with various merits like high efficiency, low cost, and environmental friendliness [1–3]. However, their oxygen-involved reactions, namely oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER), are usually confronted with sluggish kinetics [4–6]. This greatly restricts the application of ZABs and motivates researchers to invest heavily in the development of advanced bifunctional oxygen electrocatalysts. Precious metals as state-of-the-art oxygen catalysts are widely used in oxygen reactions, but their high prices, monofunctional (Pt for ORR, Ir and Ru for OER), and poor stability hinder the commercialization of ZABs [7–10]. Therefore, it is urgently demanded to develop cost-effective and highly efficient bifunctional oxygen electrocatalysts for real-world application in ZABs [11–14]. Atomically dispersed metallic catalysts, such as M-N-C (M = Fe, Co, Ni, Mn, Zn, etc.), with ultra-high metal atom utilization and unique electron structure, have shown great potential in oxygen catalysis [15–21]. Among them, Fe-N-C catalysts are preferred by researchers because Fe is the most abundant and cheapest transition metal, and the intrinsic activity of Fe-Nx moieties under alkaline conditions is much higher than that of other metal sites [22–24]. Specifically, the ultimate intrinsic activity of Fe-Nx sites is determined by the surrounding carbon microstructure, and the edge Fe-Nx sites derived from bulk Fe nanoparticles have been proven to provide higher activity than those in the plane [25–28]. Therefore, carbon enriched with edge Fe-Nx sites is expected to achieve efficient bifunctional oxygen catalytic performance. In this case, three factors need to be addressed: (I) inhibiting the agglomeration of Fe during pyrolysis to supply more edge Fe-Nx sites [29,30]; (II) creating a well-developed porous structure in carbon to guarantee the accessibility of edge Fe-Nx sites [31,32]; (III) carbon with high graphitization degree for long-term operation and preventing the deactivation of Fe sites during OER [33–35], where Fe sites are hydroxylated to nearly insulating FeOOH species [36,37]. However, methodologies in this field are rarely reported, as it is difficult to satisfy these three demanding conditions simultaneously by a simple method. In addition, the contribution of graphitic layers to edge Fe-Nx sites in catalytic processes remains elusive. Hence, developing a facile approach to prepare edge Fe-Nx site-dominated Fe-N-C catalysts and revealing relevant catalytic mechanisms are urgently imperative to promote the development of ZABs. Herein, a silica-assisted method is developed to fabricate a porous graphitic carbon enriched with edge Fe-Nx sites (Fe-N-G) as an advanced bifunctional oxygen catalyst for ZABs. Silica effectively inhibited Fe agglomeration, enabling the formation of Fe clusters rather than Fe nanoparticles during pyrolysis. The Fe clusters catalyzed the formation of dense graphitic domains in carbon, and abundantly accessible edge Fe-Nx sites were obtained in graphitic layers after acid leaching. Consequently, Fe-N-G exhibits superior activity to benchmark Pt/C and RuO2 in ORR and OER, respectively. The graphitic layers protected edge Fe-Nx sites from demetallation in carbon during ORR, endowing Fe-N-G with remarkable ORR stability. During OER, the Fe sites were proved to be converted to FeOOH species, which synergized with graphitic layers, conferring Fe-N-G with enhanced OER activity after durability test. Density functional theory (DFT) calculations reveal that the edge Fe-N4 site has a significant advantage over the in-plane Fe-N4 site regarding the dissociation of OH* in ORR and the formation of OOH* in OER. A homemade ZAB based on Fe-N-G cathode shows a favorable performance that is superior to Pt/C + RuO2 counterparts, further validating the advantages of edge Fe-Nx sites in oxygen catalysis. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis of N-G, Fe-N-G, and Fe/N-C catalysts Typically, various dosages of FeCl3 (20, 30, or 40 mg), 2 g of L-aspartic acid, and 3 mL of tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS) were transferred into a mixed solution of 100 mL of deionized (DI) water, 40 mL of anhydrous ethanol and 1 mL of ammonia solution (25 wt%). After 2 h stirring at 70 °C, another 0.5 mL of ammonia solution was injected and kept stirring for 10 h. Subsequently, after being completely dried in an oven at 80 °C, the collected powder was calcined at 600 °C in argon for 2 h, then treated with a mixed atmosphere of NH3 (50 sccm) and argon (50 sccm) at 900 °C for 1 h. Finally, the calcined powder was washed with 10 wt% HF for 8 h for removing silica and Fe-related particles. The resultant samples were named Fe-N-G-X, where X is 20, 30, and 40, corresponding to the dosage of FeCl3. In this work, Fe-N-G represents Fe-N-G-30 unless otherwise specified. In addition, two control samples were prepared according to the same procedure for Fe-N-G-X, except that FeCl3 or silica was not added, named N-G and Fe/N-C, respectively. 2.2 Materials characterizations The morphology characteristics and microstructure were investigated using scanning electron microscope (SEM, Regulus 8100) and transmission electron microscope (TEM, JEOL 2100F). STEM images were recorded using JEM-ARM-300F. The crystal structure was recorded by an X-ray diffractometer (XRD, Bruker D8 ADVANCE). The surface element components were characterized by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, Thermo, ESCALAB 250). Nitrogen adsorption and desorption isotherms were examined by a physical adsorption instrument (BELSORP-Max, Japan). Raman spectrums were recorded from XploRA PLUS. The Fe contents in the catalysts were determined by inductively coupled plasma-mass (ICP-MS, Agilent 7700X, America). FT-IR spectrum was obtained on a Nicolet iS50 FT-IR spectrometer. 2.3 Electrochemical measurements A typical three-electrode test was performed on CHI 760E. For ORR, a mixture of 5 mg catalyst, 950 μL of anhydrous ethanol, and 50 μL of Nafion solution (5 wt%) was sonicated for 30 min. Next, 12 μL of ink was transferred to the glassy-carbon electrode (d = 5 mm), yielding a catalyst loading of 0.3 mg cm−2. In the control experiment, 20 wt% Pt/C catalyst was used at 0.1 mg cm−2. Graphite robs and Ag/AgCl electrodes (saturated KCl solution) served as auxiliary and reference electrodes, respectively. The recorded potentials were calculated versus reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE). (1) E RHE =E Ag/AgCl +0.059pH+0.198 Linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) was carried out in 0.1 M KOH solution saturated with O2 and N2 at a sweep rate of 10 mV s−1. The Tafel slopes were determined by. (2) η = b l o g j + a The accelerating durability test (ADT) was conducted in the potential range of 0.6–1.0 V with a sweep rate of 50 mV s−1. For rotating ring disk electrode (RRDE) measurements, the Pt ring potential was constant at 1.3 V vs. RHE. As for OER, a mixture of 5 mg catalyst, 250 μL of DI water, and 250 μL of N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) was sonicated for 30 min. Then, the as-prepared ink was transferred to 1 cm × 1 cm nickel foam, yielding a catalyst loading of 0.5 mg cm−2. As a control catalyst, RuO2 was loaded with the same loading. Hg/HgO electrode (1.0 M KOH) was used as a reference electrode. The recorded potentials were calculated versus RHE. (3) E RHE =E Hg/HgO +0.059pH+0.098 LSV was carried out in 1.0 M KOH solution saturated with O2 at a sweep rate of 10 mV s−1 and IR corrected. ADT was conducted in the potential range of 1.2–1.6 V with a sweep rate of 100 mV s−1. For ZABs assembly, the carbon paper loaded with catalyst (loading of 1 mg cm−2) and zinc plate were used as the cathode and the anode, respectively. The electrolyte consisted of 6 M KOH and 0.2 M zinc acetate. For comparison, the Pt/C + RuO2-based ZAB was also assembled with the same catalyst loading. 2.4 Computational methods All spin-polarized calculations for geometry optimization were performed by using DFT implemented in the Vienna Ab-initio Simulation Package (VASP) [38]. The exchange–correlation interactions were approximated by the generalized gradient approximation (GGA) in the form of the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof functional (PBE) [39]. A DFT + D3 semi-empirical correction of Grimme’s scheme was employed to describe the dispersion interaction [40]. Cut-off energy of 400 eV was used for a plain-wave basis, with the energy convergence threshold set as 10−5 eV and the force convergence threshold set to 0.005 eV Å−1. The work used the cluster model, and all carbon atoms at the edges were saturated with hydrogen atoms. The vacuum space was set above 20 Å to avoid interactions between periodic images. A 4 × 4 graphene supercell, in which Fe atoms were embedded in N-decorated double vacancies, was used in the calculations. The Gibbs free energy changes (ΔG) were calculated by the following equation. (4) ΔG=ΔE+ΔZPE–TΔS+ΔG u +ΔG ph where ΔE is obtained directly from DFT calculation, ΔZPE represents the correction of zero-point vibration energy (ZPE), T is the room temperature, 298.15 K, and ΔS is the correction for entropy. ΔGu = −eU, is the electrodes potential contribution to ΔG, and ΔG ph = −ΔK Bln10*pH [41]. Here, pH was set to zero during the calculation. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structural characterization Fig. 1 depicts the fabrication procedure of Fe-N-G catalyst. In this process, TEOS was chosen to form nano silica by hydrolysis during blending. L-aspartic acid was chosen as the precursor of carbon and nitrogen, and FeCl3 as the precursor of iron. Continuous stirring of the mixed precursor solution during the hydrolysis of TEOS was conducted to ensure a homogeneous compound of silica/L-aspartic/FeCl3. During pyrolysis, NH3 was injected to provide an adequate N source for anchoring Fe atoms. Silica acted as a spatial resistance to inhibit Fe aggregation. As a result, abundant tiny Fe nanoparticles were formed and completely removed by the HF solution, thus exposing numerous accessible edge Fe-Nx sites in carbon. The distribution of Fe and the microstructure of the samples were investigated by TEM. The unwashed Fe/N-C displays obvious Fe aggregates with different nanoparticle sizes (Fig. 2 a). The lattice fringe of the encapsulated Fe nanoparticle in unwashed Fe/N-C was measured to be 2.701 Å (inset in Fig. 2b), corresponding to the (104) plane of Fe2O3. Even after HF leaching (Fig. 2c), large Fe nanoparticles can also be found in Fe/N-C. The severe aggregation of Fe and the difficulty of removing Fe nanoparticles would lead to low Fe utilization and insufficient edge Fe-Nx sites in Fe/N-C. Continuous and closed graphitic layers (Fig. 2d and inset) appear in Fe/N-C. Such structure would prevent the active sites from being infiltrated by electrolytes and lead to inferior accessibility. In sharp contrast, no apparent agglomerates can be found in unwashed Fe-N-G (Fig. 2e), implying the aggregation of Fe was effectively restrained by silica. Tiny Fe clusters and surrounding short graphitic layers are visible in unwashed Fe-N-G (Fig. 2f). Since the Fe clusters are highly dispersed and not wrapped by graphitic layers, numerous edge Fe-Nx sites located in graphitic layers can be accessed after purification. No Fe aggregates and their corresponding diffraction spots were found in Fe-N-G (Fig. 2g and h, and inset of h). In addition, Fe-N-G displays a well-developed porous structure consisting of massive small mesopores. Unlike Fe/N-C, dense graphitic domains are presented in Fe-N-G (Fig. 2i). This should be attributed to numerous Fe clusters formed during calcination, which catalyze the formation of graphitic carbon. The lattice fringe of graphitic layers was measured to be 3.53 Å, slightly larger than graphite of 3.35 Å, suggesting the C atoms might be substituted by larger Fe or N atoms in Fe-N-G. The aberration-corrected HAADF-STEM images (Fig. 2j and Fig. S1) evidence the presence of numerous single Fe atoms (marked by red circles) in the graphitic layers of Fe-N-G. Element mapping (Fig. 2k) images display that C, N, Fe, and O elements are homogeneously dispersed in Fe-N-G, and N and Fe elements are highly overlapped. The accurate Fe content in Fe-N-G was determined by ICP-MS, which shows a low Fe content of 0.28 wt%. Combining these, it can be concluded that the remaining Fe in Fe-N-G is atomically dispersed and inferred to exist mainly in the form of Fe-Nx moieties [26]. The crystalline structure and graphitization degree of the catalysts were explored with XRD and Raman spectroscopy. Both N-G, Fe-N-G, and Fe/N-C show characteristic peaks at ca. 25° and 44° (Fig. 3 a), corresponding to the (002) and (101) planes of graphitic carbon, respectively. No other crystalline diffraction peaks can be found in N-G and Fe-N-G, suggesting the complete removal of silica and Fe-related particles. While Fe/N-C shows two additional diffraction peaks at ca. 33° and 35°, corresponding to the (104) and (110) planes of Fe2O3, respectively. In particular, Fe/N-C shows a sharper peak than N-G and Fe-N-G at ca. 25° due to the stronger catalytic graphitization ability of the larger Fe nanoparticles, which results in a higher crystallinity of the surrounding carbon. Similar to N-G, Fe-N-G exhibits a broad peak at 25°, indicating a wide range of graphitic regions. The XRD results are consistence with TEM observations. Same as XRD, no characteristic peaks of Fe-related aggregates were detected in Raman spectra (Fig. 3b). The I D/I G values of N-G, Fe-N-G, and Fe/N-C are determined to be 1.01, 1.06, and 1.35, respectively. The higher I D/I G value of Fe-N-G than N-G indicates more defects formed in Fe-N-G, which might be related to edge Fe-Nx sites. The highest I D/I G value of Fe/N-C suggests its lowest graphitization degree, emphasizing the important role of silica in obtaining a stable carbon substrate. To analyze the surface elemental composition of the samples, XPS analysis was conducted. XPS spectra (Fig. S2) display C, N, and O elements contained in the three catalysts, and the Fe signal is only detected in Fe/N-C (0.23 at% of Fe, Table S1). The failure of detecting the Fe signal in Fe-N-G should be attributed to its trace amount and/or being wrapped by graphitic layers [26]. The N contents of N-G, Fe-N-G, and Fe/N-C are 7.47 at%, 4.94 at%, and 2.51 at%, respectively. It is found that the introduction of Fe leads to a lower N content of Fe-N-G and Fe/N-C than N-G, and Fe/N-C exhibits the lowest N content in the absence of silica. C 1s spectra (Fig. 3c) show that the C-N percentages in N-G, Fe-N-G, and Fe/N-C are 36.3%, 25.2%, and 18.8%, respectively. Accordingly, it can be concluded that the aggregation of iron would lead to a decrease in N content by suppressing the formation of C–N bond, and the silica can reduce the loss of N during calcination by inhibiting the formation of large iron nanoparticles. The presence of C=O bond in Fe-N-G should originate from the carboxyl group. This hydrophilic functional group can facilitate the transportation of dissolved oxygen in the porous channel. N 1s spectra (Fig. 3d) display four dominant peaks at 398.6, 399.8, 400.7, and 401.7 eV, corresponding to pyridinic N, Fe-Nx, pyrrolic N, and graphitic N, respectively [16]. Both Fe-N-G and Fe/N-C exhibit a high Fe-Nx percentage of 23.4% and 23.8% (Fig. 3e), respectively. The pyrrolic N content in N-G is 41.5%, higher than that of Fe-N-G (26.9%) and Fe/N-C (24.8%). The lower graphitic N contents of Fe-N-G and Fe/N-C indicate that the graphitization of carbon is reduced with the introduction of Fe, which is in good agreement with the Raman results. N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms (Fig. 3f) display combined characteristics of type I and type IV isotherms, demonstrating considerable micropores and mesopores in the catalysts. The specific surface areas (SSA) of N-G, Fe-N-G, and Fe/N-C are 1170, 997, and 324 m2 g−1, respectively. In comparison, the introduction of Fe in carbon leads to a decrease in SSA and silica provides a well-developed porous structure for N-G and Fe-N-G. The pore size distribution curves (Fig. S3) present that N-G, Fe-N-G, and Fe/N-C mainly display micropores and small mesopores, specifically concentrated at 0.7, 1.5, 3.1, and 5.0 nm. The purification process increases the volume of pores at 1.5, 3.1, and 5.0 nm, benefiting to improve the accessibility of Fe-Nx sites and facilitating the mass transfer in ORR and OER. 3.2 Electrochemical performance and mechanism investigation LSV measurement was performed in an O2-saturated KOH solution (0.1 M for ORR and 1 M for OER) to evaluate the activity of the samples. From Fig. 4 (a), the onset potential (E 0), half-wave potential (E 1/2), and limiting current density (J L) for Fe-N-G are 0.973 V, 0.859 V, and 4.96 mA cm−2, respectively. The ORR activity of Fe-N-G is far superior to N-G (E 0 = 0.854 V, E 1/2 = 0.762 V, J L = 3.66 mA cm−2), Fe/N-C (E 0 = 0.893 V, E 1/2 = 0.734 V, J L = 3.27 mA cm−2), and commercial Pt/C (E 0 = 0.967 V, E 1/2 = 0.832 V, J L = 5.30 mA cm−2). The inferior activity of N-G and Fe/N-C shows that the high activity of Fe-N-G mainly derives from numerous accessible Fe-Nx moieties. It should be attributed to the silica, which effectively inhibits the aggregation of iron during calcination and provides considerable pores after removal. The electron transfer number (n) was calculated based on the K-L equation (Fig. S4), and there are 2.25, 3.59, and 2.50 of N-G, Fe-N-G, and Fe/N-C, respectively. RRDE measurement (Fig. S5) also shows that Fe-N-G has a near four-electron reaction path with a much lower peroxide yield than Fe/N-C and N-G. This indicates that the ORR occurring at Fe-N-G has a high four-electron selectivity for the reduction of O2 to H2O. The kinetic current densities (J k) of N-G, Fe-N-G, Fe/N-C, and Pt/C at 0.85 V (Fig. 4b) were calculated to be 0.14, 6.07, 0.36, and 3.21 mA cm−2, respectively. In addition, Fe-N-G shows a Tafel slope (Fig. 4c) of 74.0 mV dec−1, which is much smaller than N-G (111.8 mV dec−1), Fe/N-C (123.6 mV dec−1), and Pt/C (78.5 mV dec−1). Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) depicts that Fe-N-G has the smallest semicircle diameter (Fig. S6), which relates to charge transfer resistance (R ct), indicating the fastest charge transfer. These results precisely reveal a fast reaction kinetics of Fe-N-G in ORR. Moreover, the double-layer capacitance (C dl) was calculated by CV with different scan rates (Fig. S7). Fe-N-G has the largest C dl value of 22.3 mF cm−2, followed by N-G (18.2 mF cm−2) and Fe/N-C (6.0 mF cm−2) (Fig. 4d). This means Fe-N-G has the largest electrochemical surface area, namely, the most accessible active sites. Furthermore, the methanol tolerances of Fe-N-G and Pt/C were investigated by chronoamperometry. Unlike the apparent fluctuations in the I-t curve of Pt/C (Fig. S8), Fe-N-G did not show significant fluctuation in the presence of methanol, exhibiting a better methanol resistance than Pt/C. The OER activity was also explored and the obtained LSV curves were manually compensated. Generally, the overpotential with a current density of 10 mA cm−2 (η 10) is used to judge the OER activity of the catalyst, because it is equivalent to the overpotential required when the solar cell water splitting efficiency is 12.3% [42]. Fe-N-G presents a η 10 of 344 mV, which is 10 mV less than that of RuO2 (η 10 = 354 mV) and significantly smaller than that of N-G (η 10 = 408 mV) and Fe/N-C (η 10 = 422 mV) (Fig. 3e). The combination of edge Fe-Nx sites and graphitic carbon also shows an impressive potential in OER catalysis. As depicted in Fig. 3(f), the Tafel slope of Fe-N-G (76.3 mV dec−1) is much lower than that of N-G (142.6 mV dec−1), Fe/N-C (122.3 mV dec−1), and RuO2 (127.3 mV dec−1). Fe-N-G delivers fast reaction kinetics even under harsh OER conditions. The potential gap (ΔE = Eη =10−E 1/2) of Fe-N-G was calculated to be 0.71 V, which is smaller than that of N-G (0.85 V), Fe/N-C (0.86 V), Pt/C + RuO2 (0.752 V) (Fig. 4g) and comparable to most recently reported noble metal-free bifunctional oxygen catalysts (Fig. 4h and Table S2) [43–48]. In addition to activity, stability is another index to judge the performance of the catalyst. The durability of Fe-N-G in ORR was performed with an ADT in CV with 8000 and 20,000 cycles. After 8000 cycles (Fig. 5 a and b), Fe-N-G presents almost no performance decay, while the E 1/2 of Pt/C is negatively shifted by 12 mV. Even after 20,000 cycles, the E 1/2 of Fe-N-G shifted only 17 mV negatively. Fe-N-G exhibits admirable stability that is far superior to Pt/C in ORR. To reveal the good stability of Fe-N-G, XPS was performed after ADT. XPS spectra (Fig. S9) display that S, C, N, O, F, and Fe signals were contained in Fe-N-G after ADT, where S and F signals should derive from the Nafion solution. Surprisingly, Fe-N-G shows a Fe content of 1.91 and 1.93 at% after 8000 and 20,000 cycles (Table S1), respectively. The emergence of the Fe signal indicates that the deeply buried Fe-Nx sites are gradually exposed during ADT and participated in the ORR. Notably, the N content in Fe-N-G decreased significantly after ADT, there is 1.62 at% after 8000 cycles and almost disappeared after 20,000 cycles. N 1s spectra were deconvoluted (Fig. S10) and the contents of various N species are depicted in Fig. 5(c). After 8000 cycles, Fe-N-G showed a decrease in percentage of Fe-Nx (17.8%) and pyrrolic N (22.8%) and an increase in percentage of pyridinic N (29.4%) and graphitic N (30.0%). After 20,000 cycles, the graphitic N content in Fe-N-G is significantly decreased to 8.3%, while the other three N species are increased. The results indicate that the unstable Fe-Nx sites are demetallized from carbon during ADT and more edge Fe-Nx sites are exposed and involved in the ORR. Attributed to these, Fe-N-G is allowed to exhibit a favorable ORR stability, and the observed activity deterioration after 20,000 cycles might be related to the carbon structure collapse. The OER stability of Fe-N-G was also investigated with ADT for 2000 and 4000 cycles. Impressively, the η 10 of Fe-N-G shifted positively by 14 and 9 mV after 2000 and 4000 cycles (Fig. 5d), respectively. This is in sharp contrast to RuO2 that shifted negatively by 22 mV after 2000 cycles (Fig. 5e). The results show that Fe-N-G achieves an enhanced OER activity after ADT. It has been widely reported that the metal centers would suffer from hydroxylation in OER and be converted to metal hydroxy oxides, which act as the real active centers for the OER. To confirm the formation of FeOOH after ADT, FT-IR spectroscopy was measured (Fig. 5f). Apparently, Fe-N-G shows an obvious C=O characteristic peak at 1358 cm−1 and a M=O characteristic peak at 1620 cm−1, indicating the presence of FeOOH [36,49]. Therefore, the enhanced OER activity of Fe-N-G after ADT should be attributed to the graphitic layers, which provide convenient electron transfer channels for FeOOH species to exert their high OER intrinsic activity [50–52]. Fig. 5(g) demonstrates a possible reaction mechanism of Fe-N-G during oxygen catalysis. XRD, SEM, and TEM characterizations were performed to further reveal the changes in Fe-N-G after ORR and OER. Interestingly, Fe-N-G did not show any new characteristic peaks in XRD after 8000 ORR cycles, while some new peaks appeared in Fe-N-G after 2000 OER cycles (Fig. 6 a). The new peaks appear at 16.8°, 52.0°, and 44.4°, corresponding to the (200) and (600) planes of FeOOH and (110) plane of Fe, respectively. This strongly proves that the Fe sites underwent a hydroxylation process and converted to FeOOH species during OER, which acted as real active sites for Fe-N-G in the following OER process. The appearance of Fe should be derived from the conversion of FeOOH species during the drying process. SEM images (Fig. 6b and c) reveal that Fe-N-G consisted of numerous carbon sheets with porous structures and rough surfaces. The surface of Fe-N-G becomes rougher after ORR (Fig. 6d and e) and OER (Fig. 6f and g) cycling, especially in ORR, presumably due to the etching effect of the KOH solution. Nevertheless, the sheet-like structure of Fe-N-G can still be maintained, demonstrating good structural stability. Similarly, no Fe-related nanoparticles were found in Fe-N-G after ORR (Fig. 6h), while they can be observed in Fe-N-G after OER. The observed nanoparticles near the graphitic layers show a lattice fringe of 0.333 nm (Fig. 6i), corresponding to the (310) plane of FeOOH species. For the preparation of catalysts with different amounts of edge Fe-Nx sites, the dosage of FeCl3 was varied to 20 and 40 mg, and the obtained catalysts were named Fe-N-G-20 and Fe-N-G-40, respectively. Similar to Fe-N-G, no characteristic peaks of Fe nanoparticles appeared in the XRD (Fig. S11a) and Raman (Fig. S11b) patterns of Fe-N-G-20 and Fe-N-G-40. The accurate Fe content in Fe-N-G-20 and Fe-N-G-40 was determined to be 0.21 and 0.39 wt% (from ICP-MS), respectively. Combining these, it is inferred that the residual Fe in Fe-N-G-20 and Fe-N-G-40 is also dispersed at the atomic level. In addition, it can be found that the graphitization degree of the resulted catalysts gradually increases with the increase of FeCl3 dosage. This can be attributed to the strong catalytic graphitization ability of Fe, which allows the migration and rearrangement of adjacent carbon atoms during heat treatment [53]. Likewise, no Fe signal was observed in the XPS spectra (Fig. S12) of Fe-N-G-20 and Fe-N-G-40. The N content (Table S1) in Fe-N-G-20 and Fe-N-G-40 is 6.79 and 5.68 at%, respectively. It is found that increasing the FeCl3 dosage from 20 to 30 mg results in a lower N content in Fe-N-G (4.94 at%) than in Fe-N-G-20, which should be due to the Fe atoms occupying the doping sites of the N atoms. When the FeCl3 dosage reached 40 mg, the extra Fe atoms should be involved in the anchoring of N atoms, making the N content in Fe-N-G-40 higher than in Fe-N-G. C 1s spectra (Fig. S11c) show that the C–N bond percentage of Fe-N-G (25.2%) is lower than that of Fe-N-G-20 (31.4%) and Fe-N-G-40 (26.8%). Geometrically, the exposed N atom in the edge Fe-Nx site is bonded to one carbon atom, while the internal N atom is connected with two carbon atoms. Therefore, the edge Fe-Nx sites should possess a lower C–N bond percentage than the in-plane Fe-Nx sites. The smallest C–N bond percentage of Fe-N-G indicates that its edge Fe-Nx site content should be higher than Fe-N-G-20 and Fe-N-G-40. As a consequence, low Fe content (20 mg) causes difficulty in creating edge Fe-Nx sites in the carbon layer, while high Fe content (40 mg) may cause nanostructure collapse slightly and reduce the number of edge Fe-Nx sites [27]. N 1s spectra (Fig. S11d) show that the Fe-Nx percentages in Fe-N-G-20 and Fe-N-G-40 are 26.0% and 22.7%, respectively. The contents of Fe-Nx moieties in Fe-N-G-20 and Fe-N-G-40 were calculated to be 1.77 at% and 1.29 at%, respectively, which are higher than that of Fe-N-G (1.16 at%). The N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms (Fig. S11e) and pore size distribution (Fig. S11f) indicate that the SSA and pore size of Fe-N-G-20 (996 m2 g−1) and Fe-N-G-40 (1000 m2 g−1) are similar to those of Fe-N-G. Although Fe-N-G has the lowest Fe-Nx content, Fe-N-G can exhibit higher ORR and OER activity (Fig. S13) than Fe-N-G-20 (E 1/2 = 0.834 V, η 10 = 369 mV) and Fe-N-G-40 (E 1/2 = 0.836 V, η 10 = 367 mV) owing to the presence of more edge Fe-Nx sites. This well illustrates that the activity of the edge Fe-Nx sites is higher than that of the in-plane Fe-Nx sites. 3.3 Theoretical calculations To further elucidate the superiority of edge Fe site in ORR and OER, DFT calculations were performed with a typical adsorbate evolution mechanism and PH was set to zero. Specifically, the Fe-N4 motif is selected as a model, as it is the main and most common active component in Fe-N-C catalysts [28]. A typical 4e− ORR process (Fig. 7 a) involves the following steps: (1) the O2 molecule is adsorbed on active sites and reacts with one proton to form OOH*; (2) OOH* obtains one electron and transforms into O*; (3) O* reacts with one proton to form OH*; (4) OH* combines with one proton and electron to form H2O [27]. The ORR Gibbs free energy diagram at U = 0 V (Fig. 7b and c) shows that both the in-plane Fe-N4 (i-Fe-N4) and the edge Fe-N4 (e-Fe-N4) sites have a similar rate-determining step (RDS), corresponding to the desorption of OH* in the last step. At U = 0 V, all the radical reactions in the ORR of i-Fe-N4 and e-Fe-N4 are exothermic. The desorption free energy of OH* on i-Fe-N4 is 0.3 eV while 0.59 eV for e-Fe-N4 site, demonstrating a faster OH* desorption behavior on e-Fe-N4 site. At U = 1.23 V, the RDS of i-Fe-N4 and e-Fe-N4 both are endothermic. The energy barrier of OH* desorption in i-Fe-N4 and e-Fe-N4 are 0.93 and 0.64 eV, respectively. For OER, the reaction steps reverse to the process of ORR (Fig. 7a). The OER free energy diagram of i-Fe-N4 site at U = 0 V (Fig. 7d) shows that RDS is the third step, which corresponds to O* transformed to OOH*. The RDS of i-Fe-N4 in OER is endothermic and the energy barriers of OOH* formation at U = 0 and 1.23 V are 1.66 and 0.42 eV, respectively. As for e-Fe-N4 site, the energy barriers of OOH* formation in OER at U = 0 and 1.23 V are 1.61 and 0.38 eV (Fig. 7e), respectively. This implies that e-Fe-N4 site has higher activity than i-Fe-N4 even under harsh OER conditions. DFT results confirm that e-Fe-N4 site is superior to i-Fe-N4 site in oxygen electrocatalysis. 3.4 Performance of ZABs To investigate the practical application of the as-prepared catalyst, Fe-N-G was used as a cathode to assemble ZAB (Fig. 8 a). Pt/C + RuO2-based ZAB was also assembled for comparative study. The open-circuit voltage (OCV) (Fig. 8b) of Fe-N-G-based ZAB is 1.45 V, which is comparable to that of Pt/C + RuO2-based ZAB (1.52 V). Fe-N-G-based ZAB shows higher charge–discharge current density and lower charge–discharge potential gap than Pt/C + RuO2-based ZAB (Fig. 8c), manifesting its better bifunctional oxygen catalytic performance than Pt/C + RuO2 counterparts. The peak power density (Fig. 8d) of Fe-N-G-based ZAB can reach 133 mW cm−2, much higher than that of Pt/C + RuO2-based ZAB (81 mW cm−2). Fe-N-G-based ZAB shows a specific capacity (Fig. 8e) of 802.4 mA h g−1 at a current density of 10 mA cm−2, superior to the Pt/C + RuO2-based ZAB (745.9 mA h g−1). The voltage (Fig. 8f) of Fe-N-G-based ZAB at 1 mA cm−2 could recover to 1.325 V after discharging at current densities of 1, 2, 5, 10, 20, and 50 mA cm−2 for 1 h, respectively. Although Pt/C + RuO2-based ZAB can also maintain the initial voltage after current density back to 1 mA cm−2, but its voltage gap at different current densities is much larger than that of Fe-N-G-based ZAB. This clarifies that Fe-N-G-based ZAB has a better rate performance than Pt/C + RuO2-based ZAB. The galvanostatic charge–discharge measurement at a current density of 10 mA cm−2 was performed to investigate the long-term stability of the fabricated ZABs. In sharp contrast to Pt/C + RuO2-based ZAB, whose performance decreases significantly within 125 h, Fe-N-G-based ZAB shows more stable performance during 180 h charge–discharge process (Fig. 8g). In the initial state (Fig. 8h), both Fe-N-G-based and Pt/C + RuO2-based ZABs have a similar potential gap, which is 1.002 and 0.984 V, respectively. Fe-N-G-based ZAB exhibits a potential gap of 0.929 V even after 120 h operation (Fig. 8i). After 125 h (Fig. 8j), the potential gap of Pt/C + RuO2-based ZAB reaches 1.191 V while that of Fe-N-G-based ZAB is only 0.956 V, demonstrating the potential of Fe-N-G catalyst in the application of ZABs. 4 Conclusions In summary, a silica-assisted approach has been proposed to obtain a graphitic porous carbon enriched with edge Fe-Nx sites for efficient and durable bifunctional oxygen catalytic behaviors in ZABs. Silica effectively inhibited the aggregation of iron and facilitated the formation of dense graphitic domains in carbon. The removal of Fe nanoclusters and silica has brought a high SSA of 997 m2 g−1 and exposed abundant edge Fe-Nx sites in Fe-N-G. As a result, Fe-N-G with a low Fe content of 0.28 wt% was enabled to achieve an E 1/2 of 0.859 V in ORR and a η 10 of 344 mV in OER, delivering a smaller ΔE of 0.715 V compared to Pt/C + RuO2 and most reported noble metal-free bifunctional oxygen catalysts. The extraordinary stability of Fe-N-G has been revealed to derive from graphitic layers, which have strong interactions with edge Fe-Nx sites in ORR and well exert the high intrinsic activity of FeOOH species in OER. DFT calculations have demonstrated the superiority of edge Fe-Nx sites over in-plane Fe-Nx sites in accelerating the O* dissociation for ORR and the OOH* formation for OER. The constructed ZAB based on Fe-N-G cathode exhibited a peak power density of 133 mW cm−2 and maintained a narrow potential gap of 0.929 V after 120 h operation. This work guides designing of advanced bifunctional oxygen electrocatalysts to accelerate the practical applications of ZABs. coredata.dc:description: The development of advanced bifunctional oxygen electrocatalysts for oxygen reduction and evolution reactions (ORR and OER) is critical to the practical application of zinc-air batteries (ZABs). Herein, a silica-assisted method is reported to integrate numerous accessible edge Fe-Nx sites into porous graphitic carbon (named Fe-N-G) for achieving highly active and robust oxygen electrocatalysis. Silica facilitates the formation of edge Fe-Nx sites and dense graphitic domains in carbon by inhibiting iron aggregation. The purification process creates a well-developed mass transfer channel for Fe-N-G. Consequently, Fe-N-G delivers a half-wave potential of 0.859 V in ORR and an overpotential of 344 mV at 10 mA cm−2 in OER. During long-term operation, the graphitic layers protect edge Fe-Nx sites from demetallation in ORR and synergize with FeOOH species endowing Fe-N-G with enhanced OER activity. Density functional theory calculations reveal that the edge Fe-Nx site is superior to the in-plane Fe-Nx site in terms of OH* dissociation in ORR and OOH* formation in OER. The constructed ZAB based on Fe-N-G cathode shows a higher peak power density of 133 mW cm−2 and more stable cycling performance than Pt/C + RuO2 counterparts. This work provides a novel strategy to obtain high-efficiency bifunctional oxygen electrocatalysts through space mediation.

coredata.dc:title: Edge atomic Fe sites decorated porous graphitic carbon as an efficient bifunctional oxygen catalyst for Zinc-air batteries
